awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Quantum Many-Body Control with Alkaline-Earth Atom-Arrays
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to create and control large-scale, coherent quantum many-body systems has wide-ranging implications for both technology and progress in fundamental sciences. It enables the generation and manipulation of entanglement, which forms the experimental foundation for quantum computers. It is necessary for quantum simulation, where highly-controlled experimental implementations shed light on outstanding questions in condensed matter physics, quantum chemistry, or high-energy physics. And it is an important building-block for realizing quantum-enhanced metrology schemes at the heart of future atomic clocks and sensor devices. Here, this project will implement such highly-controlled, large-scale quantum many-body systems with arrays of ultracold, alkaline-earth strontium atoms that are assembled and manipulated in an atom-by-atom fashion with optical tweezers and controlled via ultra-precise clock state manipulation. This platform has immediate usability in all three major directions of quantum science: quantum computing, quantum simulation and quantum-enhanced metrology. The broader impact of this research stems from the transformative effect that quantum technologies can have on society. Yet, quantum physics is not a part of basic education. Therefore, a primary goal of the educational and outreach program is to make quantum physics more accessible for a broader audience.

This research program directly addresses the 'experimental quantum many-body challenge' by combining elements of quantum gas microscopes, atom-by-atom assembly, and optical lattice clocks into a novel experimental platform with unique capabilities. This combination of features will enable a host of new developments, including novel atomic clocks based on single-atom control, quantum-enhanced metrology and quantum simulation schemes based on Rydberg interactions, or the bottom-up assembly of Hubbard and orbital-exchange models. Finally, this platform can realistically reach defect-free arrays of hundreds of atoms by implementing scalable atom-by-atom assembly. The aim is to combine large system sizes, precision control over individual particles, and coherent control over interaction mechanisms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the course of this CAREER project, we made substantial progress in advancing the understanding and control of quantum many-body systems using alkaline-earth atom arrays. These efforts addressed foundational challenges in quantum science and contributed to both intellectual merit and broader impacts.


The project achieved several breakthroughs in the field of quantum computing, simulation, and metrology. One of the most significant outcomes was the development of tweezer clocks, a novel platform that combines optical tweezer arrays with high-precision atomic clock transitions. This advancement provided a new approach to precision timekeeping by leveraging the individual control of atoms in a scalable array. Building on this achievement, we demonstrated how to hybridize quantum sensors and quantum computers by realizing record-fidelity two-qubit gates between ultranarrow optical clock transitions. This demonstration showed that quantum processors could be integrated with atomic clocks to achieve both computational and sensing functions within the same platform. These hybrid systems have the potential to revolutionize precision timekeeping, navigation, and secure communication technologies.


We also explored quantum chaos and thermalization, revealing universal behaviors, providing new insights into quantum randomness, and enabling novel benchmarking methods for quantum devices. As part of these efforts, we showed the first quantum advantage test for analog quantum simulators, by benchmarking the fidelity of creating so-called volume law states, achieving the maximum possibly entanglement for a given system size, and comparing the performance to state-of-the-art approximate classical algorithms, outperforming existing algorithms while developing a novel class of classical algorithms. These findings have significantly advanced the theoretical and experimental understanding of quantum many-body systems and their practical computational complexity.


The project also made significant contributions to education, outreach, and workforce development. Over its duration, it provided hands-on training to graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and early-career scientists, equipping them with the technical and theoretical expertise needed to excel in quantum science and engineering. This training emphasized not only technical skills but also interdisciplinary collaboration, preparing researchers to address complex challenges across quantum computing, metrology, and simulation. By engaging underrepresented groups in STEM through outreach activities, for example through the FUTURE and WAVE program, the project has fostered greater diversity within the quantum research community. Public presentations, workshops, and educational materials further extended the project's reach, sparking interest and understanding of quantum science among a broader audience.


Additionally, the project’s results hold promise for transformative applications in secure communication, precision timekeeping, and advanced sensing technologies. For example, the advances in scalable neutral atom platforms and high-fidelity control mechanisms directly contribute to the feasibility of next-generation quantum devices that could revolutionize fields ranging from cryptography to global navigation. The project's emphasis on practical implementation bridges the gap between fundamental research and real-world applications, ensuring its outcomes are relevant beyond academia.


In conclusion, this CAREER award has advanced both the intellectual frontiers of quantum science and its broader societal impacts. By addressing key scientific challenges and fostering a new generation of skilled researchers, the project has positioned the U.S. as a leader in quantum innovation, paving the way for future breakthroughs and widespread technological advancements.
